messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba boxes
messages.msgSnippet: I m a lurker on the list, but thought I d chime in about this question.  I work as a conservator (artwork on paper) by day, so safe storage is one thing we re
messages.messageBody:
I'm a lurker on the list, but thought I'd chime in about this question. I work as a conservator
(artwork on paper) by day, so safe storage is one thing we're concerned about. I'd avoid using
any sort of curing latex or Styrofoam product. Prolonged off-gassing can be a problem. I'm not
sure that the vapors will affect metal, but they will definitely affect silk. I'd urge you to
consider getting in touch with an objects conservator at a major museum with tsuba in their
collection. Perhaps the Museum of Fine Arts Boston, with which I am familiar.

As for foam, there is a safe foam on the market called 'Ethafoam' made by Dow chemical. There is
a company called Gaylord (www.gaylord.com) which sells it but I am sure there are others. It is
archivally sound and can be cut with scissors/knife to any shape.

-Doug Sanders
--- Ron Hartmann <swords@...> wrote:

> Wondered about using thin Styrofoam for this. Guess there would be no chemical reaction problem
> with Styrofoam? Balsa wood might be as easy to work with and more durable. Guess I'll have to
> sit down and experiment with these ideas.
>
> Ron
> STL
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: alchemyst
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: Tuesday, October 19, 2004 3:24 PM
> Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba boxes
>
>
>
> Ron -
>
> Styrofoam can be simply cut or scooped out to most
> any shape. Then covered with silk should do the
> job and look good. Not traditional maybe, but easy
> to do and looks good.
>
> Rich S
>
> ------------------------------------------------------------
> Richard Stein, PhD alchemyst@...
>
> The Japanese Sword Index
> http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/nihonto.htm

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba boxes
messages.msgSnippet: Wondered about using thin Styrofoam for this. Guess there would be no chemical reaction problem with Styrofoam? Balsa wood might be as easy to work with and
messages.messageBody:
Wondered about using thin Styrofoam for this. Guess there would be no chemical reaction problem with Styrofoam? Balsa wood might be as easy to work with and more durable. Guess I'll have to sit down and experiment with these ideas.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: alchemyst
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, October 19, 2004 3:24 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba boxes



Ron -

Styrofoam can be simply cut or scooped out to most
any shape. Then covered with silk should do the
job and look good. Not traditional maybe, but easy
to do and looks good.

Rich S

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba boxes
messages.msgSnippet: I would think if you wrapped the tusba in suranwrap and then in silk to approximate the size of the finished recess and then filled the box to desired level
messages.messageBody:
I would think if you wrapped the tusba in suranwrap and then in silk to
approximate the size of the finished recess and then filled the box to
desired level with that rubber mould making compound, let it harden. would
be a nice fit after it hardens then the silk could be fitted to the box and
there you go not too sure if there would be a moisture problem after as it
is a rubber product.
Just a thought Bob

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba boxes
messages.msgSnippet: Hi, I take a sheet of balsa wood, cut the pattern of the fitting with an xacto blade, then use mat glue and glue the silk in. ... From: Ron
messages.messageBody:
Hi,

I take a sheet of balsa wood, cut the pattern of the fitting with an xacto blade, then use mat glue and glue the silk in.
----- Original Message -----
From: Ron Hartmann<mailto:swords@...>
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com<mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Tuesday, October 19, 2004 11:35 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba boxes


Speaking of tsuba (kodogu) boxes...I've often wanted to convert these boxes to "recessed" boxes, thereby eliminating that damaging centerpiece. I've asked one "perfectionist" about doing this and his explanation was rather complex to say the least. Does anybody have a fairly simple method of converting boxes to recessed-type boxes? Will the silk liner conform into the depression okay?

Ron
STL

From: David Zincavage
To: token_kenkyu_kai@... ; mastersword53777@yahoogroups.com ; nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, October 19, 2004 11:23 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba boxes


The tsuba boxes I get from dealers in Japan are of poor construction. The centerpiece is always coming loose, exposing a couple of small nails, which could easily scratch a tsuba. Does anybody know a source of better boxes?

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba boxes
messages.msgSnippet: David, You don t understand I need projects like these to keep me busy. Idle hands are the devils work or however the saying goes. The wood costs me nothing
messages.messageBody:
David,

You don't understand I need projects like these to
keep me busy. "Idle hands are the devils work" or
however the saying goes. The wood costs me nothing as
most often I pull it out of the scrap bin (you'd be
amazed what people will throw away) and the time it
takes me to build one well that's just wasted time
between when I get off work and when the wifey gets
home. Besides I need a reason to get off my butt and
get back into the woodshop. I have so many projects on
the back burner but no real motivation to go and get
started on them. So if any of you out there would be
interested in a custom box just get a photo copy of a
Tsuba you want it for and mail it to me. I ask for a
photo copy and not a digital picture because I need a
1:1 copy to work from. I'm not going to ask anything
but shipping for the box's at least for now because
there is no timetable for completion of them. When I
start doing them to turn a profit THEN I'll start
charging for labor. But for right now I just want to
use my woodworking skills before I lose them.

Bob R

P.S. Tsuba bags are easy just get yourself some
pliable felt cut it about an 8th of an inch wider than
the Tsuba on either side and 3 times the length. Fold
the tsuba up with the felt and sew up two sides. This
should give you a flap that you can either sew velcro
onto it or get some silk string to tie the bag shut.

=====

http://asia.geocities.com/gentleman9/index.html

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba boxes
messages.msgSnippet: Bob, It s very kind of you to offer to do this, but I ve gotten infected recently with tsuba-itis and am buying the silly things right and left.  It wouldn t
messages.messageBody:
Bob,

It's very kind of you to offer to do this, but I've gotten infected recently with tsuba-itis and am buying the silly things right and left. It wouldn't be reasonable (or polite) to pester you to make custom boxes for them all.

I think there must be tsuba bags. I'll keep an eye out at the upcoming shows.

David



----- Original Message -----
From: Bob Rossman
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, July 19, 2003 5:31 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] tsuba boxes


David,

Do me a favor, if you have access to a photocopier
take a photocopy of the Tsuba you want a new box for
and mail it to me, I'll see if I can make you one that
will hold up a bit better and be a custom fit. Though
it will probably be made of Oak, Cherry, or Mahogany.
I haven't made any boxes for a while and it seems like
such a waste for that woodshop to go unused by me lol.
Only thing is you'll probably have to use the pillows
from an old box because I don't have a sewing machine
to make them. (yea I know how to sew big deal)

Bob R

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba boxes
messages.msgSnippet: ... Try using a modern carpenter s yellow glue. It will be stronger than the wood. Only use a small amount, and then either clamp or put some weight on the
messages.messageBody:
<alchemyst@...> writes:

> I have on some, removed the centerpiece and used a drop of white glue
> and replaced the centerpiece. That seems to help for normal use, but I
> still don't trust them for shipping or transport.

Try using a modern carpenter's yellow glue. It will be stronger than the
wood. Only use a small amount, and then either clamp or put some weight
on the center piece so that it stays absolutely flush while the glue
dries.

The stuff is extremely strong, you will tear the wood backing out before
breaking the joint.

- darcy

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba boxes

Try using a modern carpenter's yellow glue. It will be stronger than the
wood. Only use a small amount, and then either clamp or put some weight
on the center piece so that it stays absolutely flush while the glue
dries.

The stuff is extremely strong, you will tear the wood backing out before
breaking the joint.

- darcy

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba boxes
messages.msgSnippet: To all, While I have only been collecting for a few years, I have had very good success by simply replacing the 2 small nails with 2 very small brass flathead
messages.messageBody:
To all,
While I have only been collecting for a few years, I have had very good success by simply replacing the 2 small nails with 2 very small brass flathead wood screws. They hold exceedingly well -- it is almost impossible to manually create any rocking motion in the " centerpiece ". ( Is there a real name for these centerpieces ? ) In addition, the brass is much less likely to scratch the tsuba if they should somehow come loose.
If anyone is interested, I could find out the correct screw size and length that would be appropriate for the typical tsuba box.
Regards to all,
Chuck Granick

messages.subject: Re: tsuba boxes
messages.msgSnippet: ... which don t just fall off? I ve about every type of tsuba box known to mankind and ALL of them have that problem. NEVER ship or transport tsuba in them
messages.messageBody:
> >Is there a source of tsuba boxes which have secure centerpieces
which don't just fall off?


I've about every type of tsuba box known to mankind and ALL
of them have that problem. NEVER ship or transport tsuba in
them without protecting the tsuba from possible damage from
the $&*^%*$ little nails should centerpiece come loose. You
might also insist the those shipping tsuba to you do the same.

I have on some, removed the centerpiece and used a drop of
white glue and replaced the centerpiece. That seems to help
for normal use, but I still don't trust them for shipping
or transport.

Rich
------------------------------------------------------------
Richard Stein, PhD alchemyst@...

The Japanese Sword Index
http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/nihonto.htm
------------------------------------------------------------

You can get the expensive ones with the pillows, but for shipment I'd

there are several people online that sell these - hit Rich's site...
